aniel Brolund <daniel.brolund@...> wrote:
> Hi Nat,
> I see that my a=
pproach is very similar to yours, and the limited
> response I've gotten so=
 far is pretty much the same: you better see
> how well the tests describe =
the code!
>
> One other interesting effect is that after a while I start to=
 get
> documentation-driven tests, meaning that I put myself in the end use=
rs
> position, write the documentation for the feature I'm about to
> imple=
ment (as a good method name and a comment in the test method),
> write the =
test and asserts for it, and then implement the feature.
> After having run=
 the tests the documentation is ready to be reviewed,
> it takes about 3 se=
cs on my computer (and approx 1 sec is starting up
> JRuby).
>
> Right now =
it is a bit awkward since I write tests for the
> documentation features wh=
ich are mainly comments. I am, however, using
> documentation asserts (in t=
he comments) that actually shows up in the
> JUnit report in Eclipse, so I =
get pretty good feedback. One way of
> putting it is that I'm test-driving =
the documentation while I'm
> documentation-driving the tests... :-)
>
> I'=
m still not sure exactly the best place to use Bumblebee (or
> Protest), bu=
t I know that for API-documentation it will definitely be
> a good thing.
>=
 With TDDoc I experimented with Abbot tests ("GUI-clicking") where I
> comp=
lemented the comments with images by pulling bitmaps from the
> Swing frame=
s, and then generating JavaHelp files (using docbook), and
> it actually wo=
rked (with a few minor flaws). It should be possible to
> do the same thing=
 with Bumblebee. I don't want to start a new thread
> on whether GUI-clicki=
ng is a good way to test your application (I
> generally think it is not), =
but with automatically generated JavaHelp
> in the equation the balance mig=
ht change a bit for some people.
>
> Cheers
> Daniel, still wanting more fe=
edback
>
>

ote:

t/protest.html).

> >  One interesting effect I found when using Protest=
 is that the generated

tive on the test code that

ack on whether the tests acted
> > as
> >  a clear description of the teste=
d code's behaviour.
> >
> >  --Nat
> >
> >

> >  On 11/11/2007, Daniel B=
rolund <daniel.brolund@...> wrote:
> >  >
> >  > Hi all,
> >  > I wou=
ld really appreciate some feedback on a small framework I'm
> >  > writing =
for JUnit 4.4.
> >  >
> >  > I call it Bumblebee, and the purpose of it is =
to use comments and the
> >  > structures in the test-suites/cases/methods =
to create "human-readable"
> >  > documentation. It is especially well suit=
ed for writing snippet-heavy
> >  > documentation.
> >  >
> >  > In short, =
Bumblebee gets events from the execution of the tests
> >  > (suites/classe=
s/methods) and then parses the classes and methods for
> >  > specific comm=
ents to include.
> >  >
> >  > By default it adds the de-camelcased names o=
f the suites/cases/methods
> >  > as headings (a la agile dox), and the con=
tained comments becomes the
> >  > paragraphs.
> >  >
> >  > The comments a=
re actually handled as Ruby-strings that get executed in
> >  > a Bumblebee=
 execution context before being added to the output. The
> >  > execution c=
ontext is
> >  > a kind of DSL for including code-snippets and other things=
 needed, and
> >  > one of the core ideas of Bumblebee is that you should b=
e able to
> >  > extend that functionality easily.
> >  >
> >  > More detai=
led information about Bumblebee can be found at:
> >  >
> >  > http://www.a=
gical.com/bumblebee/bumblebee_doc.html
> >  >
> >  > which is of course gen=
erated with Bumblebee. :-)
> >  >
> >  > The concept of Bumblebee is the sa=
me as for TDDoc, which me and Joakim
> >  > Ohlrogge wrote some time ago as=
 an add-on for RMock. Unfortunately,
> >  > TDDoc became a bit of a dead-en=
d technically, and Joakim and I thought
> >  > it would be a good idea to s=
tart fresh. I happened to have the time at
> >  > the time and I started it=
 up. So, if you like Bumblebee, give half of
> >  > your credits to Joakim!=

> >  >
> >  > This is an early release, and I will be very happy for any f=
eedback I
> >  > can get to improve it.
> >  >
> >  > Cheers
